Requirements...Check?
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Rancher Advance 2 Archive (GameBoy Advance): Miscellaneous Q&A (Post New Questions Here): Requirements...Check?
By Nate Railsback on Friday, August 29, 2003 - 10:50 pm:

I'm currently raising an Antlan/Gitan, and I was shooting for the Crescent move to add to his list. The move table here says that the requirement is 600 Speed, but when I checked in with it, she said it was highly unlikely that I'd get it (I tried a few times anyway, to no avail). I've tried again at 700 Speed, and still no response. Is there a mistake in the table, or is there something I'm doing wrong?

By John Hawley on Saturday, August 30, 2003 - 05:43 am:

There may be another factor that we don't have yet. It's hard to nail it down to just one certain thing when you can't peek at the code. Now that your Spd is high enough try raising a stat that would be complementary to the move. Since it is a Cut tech, you might try raising Acc.

No promises as I am having trouble with my current Pixie getting any moves at all.

By Pattongeneral on Saturday, August 30, 2003 - 07:34 am:

This may just be a wild guess, but it seems to me that your own coaches make the likeliness of a new tech to go up. If I use my super-coaches, at least one of the areas of sparring says it'll be hard. Maybe that's the unknown factor; the super-coaches. The game tell you get get them, right?

By GoldenBoy on Saturday, August 30, 2003 - 01:28 pm:

Monster Rank is still a bigger factor in tech acquisition than
stats. You never said what rank he was Nate, but if it was C
or better, then meeting the Stat requirement should mean
you could get the tech. Just for reference here is my priority
list for things that help you get a tech:

1) Rank
2) Coach (homemade with 999 in the stat is best)
3) Stat (this is almost a tie with Coach)
4) Winning the fight (hard to do vs an uber coach, but even
lasting longer than one punch is helpful)

Pattongeneral- the ingame supercoaches are simply there
to give you an early leg up when you don't have time/
money to make better ones. When you get into the area of
Hi level stats and techs, those coaches more than likely
won't even be eligible to teach you any more, since you'll
have passed them by then.

By Pattongeneral on Saturday, August 30, 2003 - 04:01 pm:

I know...it just seemed to me that they helped.

By Nate Railsback on Saturday, August 30, 2003 - 05:07 pm:

Yoink is at Rank C, though perhaps I'll try again at B or A. In the meantime, maybe I'll try this Scissors thing...

By Jimeous on Tuesday, September 23, 2003 - 06:32 pm:

Nate if you have another look at the table, it requires an A Class monster :)

C Class is below A class :)

By Kimochi on Thursday, May 27, 2004 - 12:40 am:

I'm trying to get PetalWhirl for my Mocchi. It's a Rank C monster and has 600+ in ACC.
Everytime I take Mocchi with me, the girl at the Sparring center says "you will most likely" to learn a new move. My mocchi doesn't learn anything after the sparring. I've reloaded several times and still doesn't get the tech.

Does anybody have any idea why this is happening?

By Kimochi on Thursday, May 27, 2004 - 12:47 am:

Argh! OMG! Finally, after more than 5 times of trying, my mocchi learned Head Butt, in a Tech Sparring.

If memory serves me correctly, Head Butt is one of the basic moves. Doesn't that mean you need to get all the basic moves first?

By Infernus on Thursday, May 27, 2004 - 02:37 pm:

To answer as simply as I can: "Yes."

I don't know why you had such difficulty learning the move though, basic moves, as a general rule, seemed go_once_and_get to me.

To help you avoid this (so you can save money and lifespan), I can reccomend this to you:
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Rancher Advance 2 Archive (GameBoy Advance): The Studio (Combining/Breeding): Combining for more techs

By Kimochi on Thursday, May 27, 2004 - 02:47 pm:

Oh wow, that's...very nice and helpful info.
Thank you Infernus!
